repnme.cdata!:
Africa - WAEMU Capital Market Development
            Project : Implementation status results report

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the West Africa Economic and
            Monetary Union (WAEMU) Capital Market Development Project
            for Africa were as follows: overall outcome was moderately
            unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate;
            bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory; borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. The principal
            objective of the project was to develop the capital markets
            in the WAEMU region, and mobilize public and private
            financing for the region infrastructure development. The
            project is expected to contribute to the WAEMU countries
            efforts to achieve sustainable regional economic growth
            through the provision of efficient, region wide
            infrastructure services and greater financial market
            integration. There were some important project lessons
            learned: (i) well-identified pipeline of projects and
            actions is critical for effectively establishing a guarantee
            facility; (ii) guarantee facilities require the
            identification of strong and capacitated intermediaries
            prior to the commencement of operations; (iii) effectiveness
            conditions should be realistic; (iv) multi-donor operations
            require clear and efficient implementation arrangements; (v)
            the implementation of project activities co-financed by
            different donors created practical; and (vi) project
            supervision requires close oversight, and active
            decision-making from management in light of early warning signs.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa Region - West Africa Economic and
            Monetary Union Capital Market Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper concerns the approval
            of the Executive Directors to introduce changes to the West
            Africa Capital Market Development Project, for the West
            Africa Economic and Monetary Union (WAEMU). The proposed
            restructuring will help on several fronts to reach the
            project. Expanding the eligibility criteria for project
            financing under the line of credit will have two advantages:
            (i) bringing the program more in line with market demand by
            expanding the eligibility criteria of the credit line to
            encompass other non-road infrastructure sub-projects; and
            (ii) increasing the opportunity for regional integration
            through the financing of other non-road infrastructure
            projects. By extending the closing date by two years, there
            will be sufficient time to fully implement the reforms and
            successfully complete the project activities and to meet
            their development objectives. It is anticipated that demand
            for financing may surpass available funding. It was agreed
            that if the restructuring was completed and the
            International Development Association (IDA) credit was
            extended, Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA)
            would also extend the closing date of i t s trust fund to
            enable West African Development Bank (BOAD) to complete the
            technical assistance program. By restructuring the guarantee
            facility, Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA)
            will be able to provide guarantee to larger infrastructure
            projects presented by BOAD. Also, the Technical Assistance
            (TA) to be provided on risk mitigation will allow BOAD to
            move away from its traditional focus on financing public
            projects and help BOAD finance private infrastructure
            projects through diverse financing options. There are three
            changes: (a) expand the eligibility criteria of the LOC to
            (i) include other infrastructure projects in addition to
            roads; (ii) increase the ceiling of sub-projects be funded
            under the line of credit; and (iii) include cross-border
            projects related to food security; (b) cancel the guarantee
            facility; and (c) extend the credit closing date by two
            years from September 30, 2009 to September 30, 2011 and the
            IDA managed CIDA trust fund by two years to March 31, 2010.

repnme.cdata!:
IDA, MIGA and AfD support first regional
            guarantee facility in the West Africa Economic and Monetary
            Union to promote small- and medium-scale infrastructure projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The International Development
            Association (IDA) launched its first regional Partial Risk
            Guarantee Facility for the West African Economic and
            Monetary Union (WAEMU) countries -Benin, Burkina Faso, Cote
            d'lvoire, Mali, Niger, Guinea-Bissau, Senegal, and
            Togo. Developing a Guarantee Facility at a regional scale is
            the first for IDA. The Facility - which aims at fostering
            small and medium-scale infrastructure projects that are
            being developed in the WAEMU - is expected to set the
            framework for future private sector infrastructure
            developments in the region. The note reviews and explains
            the Facility, developed in partnership by IDA, the
            Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) and Agence
            Franqaise de Developpement (AD), which provides a menu of
            guarantee structures using streamlined procedures for small-
            and medium-scale infrastructure projects. The Guarantee
            Facility has been developed as a component of a broader
            project, whose goal is to develop capital markets in the
            region and mobilize public and private financing for the
            region's infrastructure. The wider scope of the West
            African Capital Market Development project also comprises a
            technical assistance component, and a line of credit to help
            achieve project objectives.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa Region - West African Economic and
            Monetary Union (WAEMU) Capital Market Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Capital Market Development Project
            for the countries of the West Africa and Economic and
            Monetary Union (Benin, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire,
            Guinea-Bissau, Mali, Niger, Senegal, and Togo)  to develop
            the capital markets and mobilize public and private
            financing for the region's infrastructure development.
            Specifically, the project will assist in: (a) strengthening
            the regulatory framework for capital market operations and
            building the capacity o f regional institutions involved in
            the capital markets; (b) providing medium and long-term
            finance for a broad spectrum o f public infrastructure
            projects, which will contribute to the physical integration
            among the WAEMU countries; and (c) providing political and
            commercial risk mitigation instruments to promote
            longer-term commercial financing in support o f small and
            medium-sized infrastructure projects in WAEMU countries. The
            four project components finance technical assistance, a line
            of credit to finance infrastructure projects, an IDA/MIGA
            and AFD (French Agency for Development)  Guarantee Facility,
            and project implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa Region - West Africa Capital Markets
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The purpose of the West Africa Capital
            Markets Project is to foster the development of unified
            financial markets to attain a sustainable regional
            integration, through strengthened institutional capacities,
            able to manage the sub-region's economies, and
            activities associated with the development of capital
            markets. To this end, one of its components supports the
            development of a strategy towards an integrated transport
            sector, backed by the Roads Sector Environmental and Social
            Management Framework Study, which assesses global
            environmental, and social conditions as related to road
            construction. This environmental management plan (EMP)
            reviews the study, and accordingly, identifies mitigation
            measures, applicable to the West Africa countries - Benin,
            Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Guinea Bissau, Mali,
            Niger, Senegal, and Togo - to minimize environmental
            adversity as a result of road construction. Mainly, this EMP
            endorses the Framework Study recommendations, and
            incorporates measures as follows. The West African
            Development Bank will establish environmental and social
            guidelines, provide technical assistance (TA), and ensure
            mechanisms to enforce environmental protection regulations.
            Specifically, regarding the roads sector, and following
            public awareness campaigns, member states should adopt
            directives for inclusion of precautionary clauses in road
            construction contracts that include water and soil pollution
            control, noise abatement, waste management control, and
            traffic safety measures. Additionally, environmental
            training should be provided to transport service personnel,
            executing agencies staff, and nongovernmental organizations,
            including on environmental monitoring, and the conduct of
            internal and mid-term evaluation of road construction practices.

display_title.display_title:
Région Afrique – Projet de
            marchés de capitaux en Afrique occidentale : évaluation
            environnementale : Résumé

authors.authr:
Buursink International Consultants in
            Environmental Management
